Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Tranexamic Acid Dosing in Chinese Cardiac Surgery Patients

Background: This randomised controlled trial aimed to develop a population pharmacokinetic (PK) model of tranexamic acid (TXA) in Chinese patients undergoing cardiac surgery with cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) to inform individualized dosing strategies.

Methods: Conducted at Fuwai Hospital, Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences, participants aged 18-70 years undergoing cardiac surgery with CPB were randomly assigned to high-dose (30 mg/kg bolus, 16 mg/kg/h maintenance, 2 mg/kg prime, n=7) or low-dose (10 mg/kg bolus, 2 mg/kg/h maintenance, 1 mg/kg prime, n=9) TXA groups. Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment by a blinded research coordinator. Blood samples were collected at 14 time points, and TXA concentrations were measured using liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry. The primary outcome was the PK parameters, measured perioperatively.

Results: Body weight was identified as the primary covariate affecting PK parameters. No significant influence of CPB on PK was detected. Population estimates for clearance (CL1), volume of the central compartment (V1), diffusional clearance (CL2), and volume of peripheral compartment (V2) were 4.7 L/h, 4.9 L, 17.0 L/h, and 11.1 L, respectively. No adverse events were reported.

Interpretation: This study provides the first population PK model of TXA in the Chinese population, suggesting target-controlled infusion as a viable option for individualized dosing. The model could serve as a reference for future development of TXA administration strategies. Trial registration: N/A. Funding: Not specified.
